intro: Arabis ochroleuca, commonly known as the yellow whitlow grass, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its basal rosette of elliptic, waxy leaves and produces clusters of small, yellow flowers with four petals. The plant is native to Europe and parts of Asia, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. It thrives in temperate climates and is known for its ability to tolerate dry conditions. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
